rev.comment: Undid revision 422977361 by [[Special:Contributions/StoneCold45|StoneCold45]] ([[User talk:StoneCold45|talk]]) Fixed dead link issue
rev.diff:
Line 194: Line 194:
Twenty-six-year-old [[Asmaa Mahfouz]] was instrumental<ref>Mekay, Emad (11 February 2011). [http://ipsnews.net/news.asp?idnews=54439 "Arab Women Lead the Charge"]. ''[[Inter Press Service]]''. Retrieved 14 March 2011.</ref> in having sparked the protests that began the uprising in Cairo.<ref>{{cite news |author=[[Transcript (law)|Transcript]]| title = Women Play Vital Role in Egypt's Uprising | url = http://www.npr.org/2011/02/04/133497422/Women-Play-Vital-Role-In-Egypts-Uprising | date = 4 February 2011 | publisher = ''[[Tell Me More]]'' (via [[NPR]]) | accessdate = 14 March 2011}}</ref> In a video blog posted two weeks before the start of the revolution,<ref>{{cite news |author=[[Staff writer]]| title = Revolutionary Blogger Asma Threatened â Activist Got Calls from NDP Party Members Ordering Her Not To Leave Home or Get Killed | date = 5 February 2011 | url = http://gulfnews.com/news/region/egypt/revolutionary-blogger-asma-threatened-1.757171 | work = [[Gulf News]] | accessdate = 14 March 2011}}</ref> she urged the Egyptian people to join her in a protest on 25 January in Tahrir Square to bring down Mubarak's regime.<ref>{{registration required|date=March 2011}} [http://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/02/world/middleeast/02iht-letter02.html?_r=1]. ''[[The New York Times]]''.</ref> She used [[video blogging]] and [[social media]] that went [[Viral video|viral]]<ref>[[Xeni Jardin|Jardin, Xeni]] (2 February 2011). [http://boingboing.net/2011/02/02/egypt-the-viral-vlog.html Egypt: The Viral Vlog of Asmaa Mahfouz That Helped Spark an Uprising"]. ''[[Boing Boing]]''. Retrieved 14 March 2011.</ref> and urged people not to be afraid.<ref>[[Staff writer]] (5 February 2011). [http://www.thecanadiancharger.com/page.php?id=5&a=774 "Asmaaa Mahfouz, a Woman Behind Egypt's Pro-Democracy Revolution"]. ''[[The Canadian Charger]]''. Retrieved 14 March 2011.</ref> The [[April 6 Youth Movement]] was a major supporter of the protest and distributed 20,000 leaflets saying "I will protest on 25 January to get my rights."
Twenty-six-year-old [[Asmaa Mahfouz]] was instrumental<ref>Mekay, Emad (11 February 2011). [http://ipsnews.net/news.asp?idnews=54439 "Arab Women Lead the Charge"]. ''[[Inter Press Service]]''. Retrieved 14 March 2011.</ref> in having sparked the protests that began the uprising in Cairo.<ref>{{cite news |author=[[Transcript (law)|Transcript]]| title = Women Play Vital Role in Egypt's Uprising | url = http://www.npr.org/2011/02/04/133497422/Women-Play-Vital-Role-In-Egypts-Uprising | date = 4 February 2011 | publisher = ''[[Tell Me More]]'' (via [[NPR]]) | accessdate = 14 March 2011}}</ref> In a video blog posted two weeks before the start of the revolution,<ref>{{cite news |author=[[Staff writer]]| title = Revolutionary Blogger Asma Threatened â Activist Got Calls from NDP Party Members Ordering Her Not To Leave Home or Get Killed | date = 5 February 2011 | url = http://gulfnews.com/news/region/egypt/revolutionary-blogger-asma-threatened-1.757171 | work = [[Gulf News]] | accessdate = 14 March 2011}}</ref> she urged the Egyptian people to join her in a protest on 25 January in Tahrir Square to bring down Mubarak's regime.<ref>{{registration required|date=March 2011}} [http://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/02/world/middleeast/02iht-letter02.html?_r=1]. ''[[The New York Times]]''.</ref> She used [[video blogging]] and [[social media]] that went [[Viral video|viral]]<ref>[[Xeni Jardin|Jardin, Xeni]] (2 February 2011). [http://boingboing.net/2011/02/02/egypt-the-viral-vlog.html Egypt: The Viral Vlog of Asmaa Mahfouz That Helped Spark an Uprising"]. ''[[Boing Boing]]''. Retrieved 14 March 2011.</ref> and urged people not to be afraid.<ref>[[Staff writer]] (5 February 2011). [http://www.thecanadiancharger.com/page.php?id=5&a=774 "Asmaaa Mahfouz, a Woman Behind Egypt's Pro-Democracy Revolution"]. ''[[The Canadian Charger]]''. Retrieved 14 March 2011.</ref> The [[April 6 Youth Movement]] was a major supporter of the protest and distributed 20,000 leaflets saying "I will protest on 25 January to get my rights."
â
Many political movements, opposition parties and public figures chose to support the day of revolt including [[Youth for Justice and Freedom]], [[Coalition of the Youth of the Revolution]], the [[Popular Democratic Movement for Change]] and the [[National Association for Change]]. However, its leader [[Mohamed El Baradei]], did not support the protests saying that he "would like to use the means available from within the system to effect change."<ref>{{cite news|last=Shenker|first=Jack|title=Mohamed ElBaradei Warns of 'Tunisia-Style Explosion' in Egypt â Mohamed ElBaradei Says Egyptians 'Yearning for Change', But Draws Criticism for Refusing To Back Street-Level Protests|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/jan/18/mohamed-elbaradei-tunisia-egypt|accessdate=14 March 2011|work = [[The Guardian]]|date=18 January 2011|location=London}}</ref> The [[Ghad party|Ghad]], [[Karama party|Karama]], [[Wafd party|Wafd]] and [[Democratic Front Party (Egypt)|Democratic Front]] Many others became involved in support of the protests. The Muslim Brotherhood, Egypt's largest opposition group,<ref name="Tagammu and Coptic Church" /> confirmed on 23 January that it will partake in the protests and participate.<ref name="Tagammu and Coptic Church" /><ref>{{cite news|last= |first= |title=MB Chairman Confirms Group Will Take Part in Day of Rage March Despite Threats |url= http://ikhwanweb.com/article.php?id=27905 |accessdate=25 March 2011 |work =Muslim Brotherhood official site |date=23 January 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last= |first= |title=Egypt Muslim Brotherhood to participate in 25 January protest |url=http://news.egypt.com/en/2011012313371/news/-egypt-news/egypt-muslim-brotherhood-to-participate-in-25-january-protest.html |accessdate=25 March 2011 |work =Egypt News |date=23 January 2011}}</ref> Public figures including novelist [[Alaa Al Aswany]], writer [[Belal Fadl]], and actors [[Amr Waked]] and [[Khaled Aboul Naga]] announced they would also participate. The Facebook group set up specifically for the event attracted 80,000 attendees. However, the [[left-wing politics|leftist]] [[National Progressive Unionist Party]] (the Tagammu) stated it would not participate. The Coptic Church also urged Christians not to participate in the protests.<ref name="Tagammu and Coptic Church">{{cite news|last=Afify|first=Heba|title=Activists Hope 25 January Protest Will Be Start of 'Something Big'|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/activists-25-january-protest-be-start-something-big|accessdate=14 March 2011|work = [[Almasry Alyoum]]|date=24 January 2011}}</ref>
+
The protests were illegal, since permission required to proceed with the demonstration had not been acquired, and the security forces had to respond according to law.<ref>{{cite news|title=Security Forces To Deal Strictly with 'Illegal' 25 January Protest|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/303405|accessdate=12 February 2011|work = [[Almasry Alyoum]]|date=23 January 2011}}</ref> Many political movements, opposition parties and public figures chose to support the day of revolt including [[Youth for Justice and Freedom]], [[Coalition of the Youth of the Revolution]], the [[Popular Democratic Movement for Change]] and the [[National Association for Change]]. However, its leader [[Mohamed El Baradei]], did not support the protests saying that he "would like to use the means available from within the system to effect change."<ref>{{cite news|last=Shenker|first=Jack|title=Mohamed ElBaradei Warns of 'Tunisia-Style Explosion' in Egypt â Mohamed ElBaradei Says Egyptians 'Yearning for Change', But Draws Criticism for Refusing To Back Street-Level Protests|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/jan/18/mohamed-elbaradei-tunisia-egypt|accessdate=14 March 2011|work = [[The Guardian]]|date=18 January 2011|location=London}}</ref> The [[Ghad party|Ghad]], [[Karama party|Karama]], [[Wafd party|Wafd]] and [[Democratic Front Party (Egypt)|Democratic Front]] Many others became involved in support of the protests. The Muslim Brotherhood, Egypt's largest opposition group,<ref name="Tagammu and Coptic Church" /> confirmed on 23 January that it will partake in the protests and participate.<ref name="Tagammu and Coptic Church" /><ref>{{cite news|last= |first= |title=MB Chairman Confirms Group Will Take Part in Day of Rage March Despite Threats |url= http://ikhwanweb.com/article.php?id=27905 |accessdate=25 March 2011 |work =Muslim Brotherhood official site |date=23 January 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last= |first= |title=Egypt Muslim Brotherhood to participate in 25 January protest |url=http://news.egypt.com/en/2011012313371/news/-egypt-news/egypt-muslim-brotherhood-to-participate-in-25-january-protest.html |accessdate=25 March 2011 |work =Egypt News |date=23 January 2011}}</ref> Public figures including novelist [[Alaa Al Aswany]], writer [[Belal Fadl]], and actors [[Amr Waked]] and [[Khaled Aboul Naga]] announced they would also participate. The Facebook group set up specifically for the event attracted 80,000 attendees. However, the [[left-wing politics|leftist]] [[National Progressive Unionist Party]] (the Tagammu) stated it would not participate. The Coptic Church also urged Christians not to participate in the protests.<ref name="Tagammu and Coptic Church">{{cite news|last=Afify|first=Heba|title=Activists Hope 25 January Protest Will Be Start of 'Something Big'|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/activists-25-january-protest-be-start-something-big|accessdate=14 March 2011|work = [[Almasry Alyoum]]|date=24 January 2011}}</ref>
